subject: Welcome to the ZB group!
content:
Hello and welcome to the ZB group!

This group is dedicated to discussion of the Zborowski-Bruchem
speedsolving method.  This group is open to learners, skeptics, or
anyone who just wants to find out what the ZB method is about.

I am personally learning ZB and feel that it has potential to be a
fast method.

Feel free to post anything about ZB on this group.

Chris

After coming back from Orlando, my girlfriend has decided to work very
hard at getting her average sub-20, and she's busy already learning
COLL and OLL to catch up to me.  For moral support (read: to stay
slightly ahead of her) I've taken to starting ZBF2L as of tonight.

She has already figured out how to orient edges from the two main
cases for the fourth pair intuitively.

I'm going to have to adopt Chris and Bob's learning pace to have any
hope of maintaining my marginal edge over her.

What an odd problem to have. ;)

-Mike Bennett

subject: How I learn ZB and can this be improved on?
content:
Hey everyone,

I hope this group continues to grow as I would really like to see this
method become mainstream one day in the future, assuming is has the
potential of course.

Here is how I have learned what I know of ZB so far.  It has worked
for me, but I don't know if it is the best way.  I would like this
thread to be a discussion of the most efficient way to learn ZB.

I guess this of course assumes you already know all of OLL and PLL. 
Or at the very very least all of PLL.

Very first beginnings:
I guess at the very start I learned the COLL algs before anything
else.  COLL recognition is such a core part of ZBLL recognition, that
I think it is very important to learn these very early on.

Moving on:
After COLL I moved on to ZBF2L algs.  I was basing off Macky's quote
that "It's all about F2L" and I think for ZB it will most definitely
be true that "It's all about ZBF2L" in terms of whether a solve is a
good solve or not.  I've known the ZBF2L algs now for 8 months and I
am starting to see the intuition on all but the most obscure cases.  I
think my ZBF2L is fairly fast, though still needs lots of improvement,
and is probably only about 2 seconds slower than my Fridrich F2L, and
on a good ZB average (sub-17) probably only 1 second or less.

Moving on from ZBF2L:
Ok so I saved ZBLL for last since it is so ridiculously huge.  I am
learning this by orientation cases with COLL cases as subgroups within
an orientation case.  I like this way since you can practice the algs
by learning the transformation algs from your unknown OLL case into a
known OLL case.  I think this aids with learning, but is probably not
the most optimal way for maximizing your speed while learning.  I
think optimally you should take your slowest COLL case and learn all
the ZBLL algs for it.  Then move on to your next slowest, until you
know all 40 COLL cases.

---------

Side notes:
I think OLL, although not necessary for true ZB, should be required
for learning ZB.  I've found that sometimes I can use a multislotting
trick to solve the 3rd and 4th corner edge pair very quickly and save
a second or two.  In this situation I would much rather do that, then
end with OLL and PLL than to solve the 3rd pair only, then hope for a
good ZBF2L for the 4th pair, then hope for a ZBLL case that you know.

I think when you know 100% ZBLL this might also still be fast,
assuming you have a well refined OLL/PLL combo.

----------------

I have no idea if this is the most efficient way, but I like the
ability to know just based on orientation whether or not I know a
case.  For example if I see the T orientation I know immediately that
I can do ZBLL.  If I see the "L" I know I don't know any algs for it
and would just use COLL/PLL.

I think having your ZBLL algs spread out over different OLL cases by
learning your slowest COLL case would probably be faster in the long
run, but would take my skill with recognition when first starting with
ZBLL.

Also I think COLL/PLL is a bad idea for COLL cases you don't know.  It
can be fast, and the 1/12 PLL skip is nice, but some of the algs are
so horribly slow for COLL.  I think maybe using only fast COLL cases
would be the best idea.  The rest of the time you could just do OLL/PLL.

Anyone have any opinions here?

----------------

Let's try to figure out the best way to learn this method.  I really
don't feel that the number of ZBLL algs is too many, even for
recognition.  However, in terms of learning them I think there must be
better ways to approach it than others.

Chris

subject: Learning pace for ZBF2L (how to learn it quickly)
content:
More posts here, I'm trying to start as many discussion threads as I can.

When I first started learning ZBF2L, my first jump into ZB algs, I
felt overwhelmed at first on how to learn them.  Pretty quickly though
I adopted a technique that worked very well for me, and let me average
almost 2.5 algs per day.

Within each ZBF2L case there are 8 edge cases (fewer for nicely
symmetric F2L cases).

Here is how you can approach an F2L case (all 8 subcases) and learn
them in three days or less and average 2.5-4 algs per day for learning.

Day 1:
Look at all 8 algs for your chosen F2L case.  Do them over an over
again on your cube.  Don't just do the alg, but set up with the
inverse of the solving alg so each time you see the case the algs
solves.  Concentrate today only on how to differentiate each case from
the other 7.  Give them names, or associate them with a picture.  Just
be able to know how to "see" each case today.  Try to setup and solve
each alg 20 times or so.

Day 2:
Again try to do each alg about 20 times by setting it up and then
solving it.  Today though, focus on memorizing the first 2-3 moves of
each alg.  You should already comfortably be able to diffentiate them,
now just associate with each case the first say 2 moves of the alg to
solve it.  Remember to do each alg 20 times at least though still.

Day 3:
Still do each alg 20 times each at least, but now focus on each alg
individually and associate with your already memorized first 2-3 moves
with the rest of the alg.  So once you have done the first 2-3 moves
you will be able to recall the rest of the alg.  After having done
each case at least 60 times already this is easier than it sounds.

Now you know all 8 cases fairly solidly within 3 days (sometimes 2). 
That's a 2.5 algs per day rate.  You will be able to recall the algs
on a speedsolve but you might delay up to 10-20 seconds or more to
recall it.  You will, however, retain all 8.

After 2-3 weeks you will recognize each case fairly quickly in a
speedsolve with minimal delay.

After 1 month on average for me, I could recognize all 8 cases within
an F2L case extremely smoothly with hardly any delay other than the
occasional amnesia.

Chris

subject: Re: Learning pace for ZBF2L (how to learn it quickly)
content:
I like your idea about spreading the learning out over several days,
but in practice, I've found I retain algs better if I learn only a few
at a time, and practice them until they're second nature.

I have a few algs from some COLL cases I've learned, and one ZBF2L
case I've learned where I'm getting major amnesia, to the point that
I'm going to go back, re-work them out with paper, and memorize the
night away as soon as I'm done on this post.  They are all from days
where I learned several algs and practiced all of them.

When I learn an alg, regardless of how many or few others I've learned
recently, I always practice it.  Generally, about a dozen or so times,
just to get the feel of it, and at least two averages worth after
that.  The next day or so, I do the same.  This usually works well for
me, but for those few cases where I attempted to learn several at a
time, I'm starting to get major amnesia anyhow.  Your mileage may
vary, though.

Maybe I'm just a slow learner. ;)

-Mike

subject: Learning pace for ZBLL (how to learn it quickly)
content:
It took me 5 months to learn the T orientaton, but I think an entire
orientatiton can be learned in 4.5 months as you get further into ZBLL
learning.

How I do it is this.  For each ZBLL case I use ACube to find algs in
the metrics I like.  I usually search for quarter turn optimal algs in
the [RUL] group or [RUF] group first.  I have ACube display all algs,
not just optimal cases.

Then I have ACube search for all algs with all available moves and I
have it display all algs found, not just optimal cases.

Then I sift through the huge lists of algs to find the good ones (most
are easily recognizable as horrible algs for speedcubing).

I then get down to 2-3 algs that are very nice.  I then use Netcube to
time each alg.  I don't memorize the algs I just read them off and
time my execution of each one.  After 20-30 repeitions you can do each
of the 2-3 algs without reading off the ACube printout since they are
in very short term memory.  Play with each alg and find the one that
seems to be the fastest.

Now that you have chosen an alg, do it 30-40 more times and time each
trial with ACube.  By this point it is fairly well in your short term
memory.  Then before you go to bed do the alg a few times again and by
then you will have it memorized fairly well and can use it in speedsolves.

It usually takes ACube a day to a day and a half to find algs, then I
spend either the second half day or full day trying to find the best
alg and learn it.  So for ZBLL I average about 2 days per alg.  For
you guys learning from either my or Dan's site I imagine you can learn
faster since you can skip the alg searching phase.

I've found that often I really dislike the Bernard Helmstetter algs,
so I will continue to generate all of mine with ACube.

If anyone is interested I can post the results for each case, or at
least the algs that I sift through to be the best ones.  I don't have
the files for most of the T cases, but I do for the last 1 or 2 COLL
cases as well as all the U cases I know so far.

Let me know if you're interested in this fairly good algs.  People
have different styles, so I may have weeded out an alg that you would
have kept though, so these lists might still not be optimal for your
hands.

Chris

subject: Re: How I learn ZB and can this be improved on?
content:
> I think having your ZBLL algs spread out over different OLL cases by

Typo.  Should be "but would take *more* skill with recognition when

algs.

-Mike

subject: Re: Learning pace for ZBF2L (how to learn it quickly)
content:
My approach to learning COLL was similar to your approach of learning
ZBF2L, but a little different.  I learned COLL in about 13 days, so it
was just about 3 algs per day.  This is what I did:

Day 1:  Learn how to perform/finger trick every alg of a given
orientation.  For example, all 6 of the "T" orientation.  Don't worry
about what they look like, just keep on performing them over and over
so your hands know how to do it.

Day 2:  Decide how you want to recognize that case and spend the
entire day distinguishing between each case and associating each alg
to their respective cases.

**Note:  I learned COLL over the summer.  Even though I was working, I
had no schoolwork and could devote several hours per day to learn
algorithms.

~ Bob

subject: learning ZB and practicing your old method
content:
What is the best way to do this?  I've found that long periods of
practicing only ZB do not make my Fridrich times worse, and often
switching back to Fridrich I get averages that, for me, are quite good.

My guess is that the number of algs required for Fridrich "seems"
fewer than before after being used to ZB recognition and that I make
decisions fairly fast, again fast for me, at each step.

I've noticed that around tournament time I stop practicing ZB
altogether in order to make sure I'm ok for Fridrich, which means 2-4
weeks of no learning for ZB.

Is there a way to balance, or is this stop and start the best way to
learn ZB and yet still be competitive in competitions?

What does everyone think?  Any ideas?  I seem to be using this stop
and start technique.  Stop learning ZB before a tournament and start
again right afterward.  Is there a better way to balance two methods,
or not really?

Chris

subject: Re: learning ZB and practicing your old method
content:
Well, of course, since PLL is involved in ZB, it is only the OLL that
you would have to worry about forgetting.  However, I am sure you have
known the OLLs long enough now that you probably won't ever forget
them, even if you never practice them again.  Since there is less to
look for in OLL than ZBLL, your recognition should be fast in comparision.

I think start/stop is the best approach.  I think my approach will
probably be to start ZB and then not stop ZB except for competitions.
 Even then, though, I think I want to only practice Fridrich at the
competition, since I plan on eventually abandoning it (unless I decide
ZB will be slower than Fridrich for me).  I am looking at the big
picture:  2-4 weeks of stopping ZB to practice Fridrich means that it
will take me an extra 2-4 weeks to learn ZB.  Multiply this time by
every competition (and you know I go to a lot of them) and it will add
a significant amount of learning time.  I am not sure of this yet
because I am not in this situation yet, but this is my plan as of now.

~ Bob

subject: My approach to learning ZB
content:
Hi guys,

For a while I had been debating on what the best way to learn ZB would
be; if it would be better to learn ZBF2L then ZBLL, or learn ZBLL then
ZBF2L.  I think I've come up with a pretty good way to do both though,
and I'm going to try using it from now on.

I know about 40 ZBF2L algs so far.  Going by Chris' ZBF2L page, I know
all of cases 1, 2, 3, 5, and 13 (including reflections).  I can
convert any case that I don't know into case 1 or 13 very easily, and
the ones that aren't easy to convert I know the ZBF2L cases for
(excluding case 4, which I'll learn next).  So, I can use ZBF2L on
every solve without too much extra effort.  I feel I can use this to
my advantage to start working on ZBLL now.  It seems pointless to
start ZBLL without knowing any of ZBF2L, but if I can use ZBF2L on
every solve even without knowing that many cases, then why not start
learning ZBLL?  At the same time though, I don't want to completely
abandon learning ZBF2L algs.  So here's what I've decided to do.  For
ZBF2L, I'm going to use Chris' technique of spreading each case out
over a three day time span and learning them all on the third day.  At
the same time though, I will try and learn one ZBLL each day.  So, for
approximately every 8 ZBF2L algs, I will learn 3 ZBLL algs.  I think
this should be completely managable, and this is nice because by the
time I'm done learning ZBF2L, I'll already have a decent chunk of ZBLL
down (about 1 1/2 orientation cases).  With practice, I think that one
ZBLL case per day is very doable, and Chris has already proven that
his 3 day ZBF2L method works fine, so why not combine the two?

Of course, if this does prove to be too much, I will try a different
learning method.  However, this sounds like a nice way to focus both
on ZBF2L and ZBLL without overloading your brain.

Let me know what you guys think!

-Jason

subject: ZBLL averages
content:
Hey everyone,

These are my first ever ZBLL averages.  I only know the T, so I had to
set it up with a transformation if it wasn't already a T case after ZBF2L.

For solves that were already the T orientation after ZBF2L I tried to
start from a random angle, and when I needed to do a transformation
into T I did the transformation without looking then started the timer
when I first saw each case.  So basically these averages include the
recognition time for ZBLL as well.

05.50, 05.99, 05.35, 05.25, 04.98, 06.58, (03.22), (07.97), 07.12,
06.67, 05.64, 6.56 = 5.96

05.34, 09.58, 04.88, 06.94, 05.50, 05.29, (09.94), 05.11, 06.83,
04.36, 05.05, (03.04) = 5.89

That's actually pretty good for me even if I was doing Fridrich LL.  I
had some long delays on the case 6 algs for my ZBLL T algs since I
recently learned them.  I think in 6 months when I know all the T algs
second nature that I can easily get sub-5 on average.  So I think a
sub-5 average is possible for ZBLL algs that you know very well. 
Maybe after 2-3 years of knowing ZBLL that could even get to low 4.xx,
who knows?  With all easy cases I think a sub-4 might be possible,
though those types of averages would be infrequent.

Anyway I thought this was promising, since it shows that even with
delays on cases that I recently learned, I can get times that compare
to a fairly good Fridrich LL average (for me).

I think ZBLL will definitely be managable, even with recognition.

Chris

> then you will have it memorized fairly well and can use it in 
speedsolves.
> 
> It usually takes ACube a day to a day and a half to find algs, 
then I
> spend either the second half day or full day trying to find the 
best
> alg and learn it.  So for ZBLL I average about 2 days per alg.  For
> you guys learning from either my or Dan's site I imagine you can 
learn
> faster since you can skip the alg searching phase.
> 
> I've found that often I really dislike the Bernard Helmstetter 
algs,
> so I will continue to generate all of mine with ACube.
> 
> If anyone is interested I can post the results for each case, or at
> least the algs that I sift through to be the best ones.  I don't 
have
> the files for most of the T cases, but I do for the last 1 or 2 
COLL
> cases as well as all the U cases I know so far.
> 
> Let me know if you're interested in this fairly good algs.  People
> have different styles, so I may have weeded out an alg that you 
would
> have kept though, so these lists might still not be optimal for 
your
> hands.
> 
> Chris
>

subject: Re: learning ZB and practicing your old method
content:
Hey friends,
     Here's my ideas.  I think practicing ZB would overall enhance 
the ability to 'look ahead and recognize', as it, I think, is 
a 'newer level' of concentration.  I practiced ZB back in '04 and 
learned quite a bit- the times were overall better for most of the 
last layer cases I was working on, but the recognition was insane.  
Practicing this recognition i think would give even better times in 
Fridrich than before...  I thought about this "stop and start" 
technique before, too...  Interesting that it works for you, Chris.  
-brent_m



--- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@h...> wrote:
>
> What is the best way to do this?  I've found that long periods of
> practicing only ZB do not make my Fridrich times worse, and often
> switching back to Fridrich I get averages that, for me, are quite 
good.
> 
> My guess is that the number of algs required for Fridrich "seems"
> fewer than before after being used to ZB recognition and that I 
make
> decisions fairly fast, again fast for me, at each step.
> 
> I've noticed that around tournament time I stop practicing ZB
> altogether in order to make sure I'm ok for Fridrich, which means 
2-4
> weeks of no learning for ZB.
> 
> Is there a way to balance, or is this stop and start the best way 
to
> learn ZB and yet still be competitive in competitions?
> 
> What does everyone think?  Any ideas?  I seem to be using this stop
> and start technique.  Stop learning ZB before a tournament and 
start
> again right afterward.  Is there a better way to balance two 
methods,
> or not really?
> 
> Chris
>

subject: Re: ZBLL averages
content:
Chris,
     what do you think about the zbll cases that actually require 
more moves (and possibly takes more time to execute) to solve than 
the oll/pll setup for that case?  I guess it can be argued that the 
zbll alg is 'one step less' than the oll/pll setup, but what if the 
oll/pll setup is actually faster than the zbll case...  Anyone?  
I've experienced this problem...
-Brent M


--- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@h...> wrote:
>
> Hey everyone,
> 
> These are my first ever ZBLL averages.  I only know the T, so I 
had to
> set it up with a transformation if it wasn't already a T case 
after ZBF2L.
> 
> For solves that were already the T orientation after ZBF2L I tried 
to
> start from a random angle, and when I needed to do a transformation
> into T I did the transformation without looking then started the 
timer
> when I first saw each case.  So basically these averages include 
the
> recognition time for ZBLL as well.
> 
> 05.50, 05.99, 05.35, 05.25, 04.98, 06.58, (03.22), (07.97), 07.12,
> 06.67, 05.64, 6.56 = 5.96
> 
> 05.34, 09.58, 04.88, 06.94, 05.50, 05.29, (09.94), 05.11, 06.83,
> 04.36, 05.05, (03.04) = 5.89
> 
> That's actually pretty good for me even if I was doing Fridrich 
LL.  I
> had some long delays on the case 6 algs for my ZBLL T algs since I
> recently learned them.  I think in 6 months when I know all the T 
algs
> second nature that I can easily get sub-5 on average.  So I think a
> sub-5 average is possible for ZBLL algs that you know very well. 
> Maybe after 2-3 years of knowing ZBLL that could even get to low 
4.xx,
> who knows?  With all easy cases I think a sub-4 might be possible,
> though those types of averages would be infrequent.
> 
> Anyway I thought this was promising, since it shows that even with
> delays on cases that I recently learned, I can get times that 
compare
> to a fairly good Fridrich LL average (for me).
> 
> I think ZBLL will definitely be managable, even with recognition.
> 
> Chris
>

subject: Re: ZBLL averages
content:
--- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, "Brent Morgan"
<brentmorganmaster@y...> wrote:
>
> Chris,
>      what do you think about the zbll cases that actually require 
> more moves (and possibly takes more time to execute) to solve than 
> the oll/pll setup for that case?  I guess it can be argued that the

> oll/pll setup is actually faster than the zbll case...  Anyone?  
> I've experienced this problem...

I think that seems really rather rare or at least very unlikely.  The
shortest possible OLL/PLL situations not involving skips are 13 moves
long.  I think these account for less than 1% of cases.

As near as I can tell, the average for a ZB finish is something like
13 or fewer moves.

-Mike

subject: Re: [zbmethod] Re: ZBLL averages
content:
Fewest moves doesn't necessarily mean fastest times, so the average for zb will be around 13-14, yep.  And the oll/pll situation is not as rare as you think. :)  Nonetheless, the problem still exists.
-Brent M

subject: Re: ACube
content:
Hey Santiago,

What I do is this.  Open up the command window by clicking on "start",
then "run", then type in "command" and click on "OK"

If you don't use windows then get to a place where you can run a java
program from a command screen.

In the windows command program you have to change directories to where
your files are for ACube using the tradional DOS directory commands.

Once you get to the right directory, type in this

java -cp ACube3.jar ACube

Now after that line you have a few options for attributes.  You can
have the program search in either face turn metric, slice turn metric,
or quarter turn metric.  Your other options are to search for optimal
length algs or algs of any length, and also for the program to print
out every alg it finds or only a small portion.

The commands I use to search for ZBLL algs are these:

java -cp ACube3.jar ACube q a

The "q" means to search in quartern turn metrics and the "a" means
print out every single alg.

Once I've analyzed the positions in that metric I exit the program
with "Ctrl + C" and start it again with

java -cp ACube3.jar ACube a

This searches in face turn metric (face turn is the default) and
prints out every alg it finds.

I then compare the best quarter turn algs and best face turn algs and
try to find the best alg among those.  If you are comfortable with
slice moves, which I am not, then you would also want to use this
search string

java -cp ACube3.jar ACube s a

--------------

Once in ACube you have to decide which types of turns you want to
allow, and you have to input the position.

While in quarter turn searching (java -cp ACube3.jar ACube q a) I
often start with searching for [RUL] only algs.  To do this I have to
come up with the octet that represents R U and L only.

The order of the faces is UDFBLRESM

I only want to allow R U and L so I would go through and put a "0" on
the face I don't want to allow and a "1" on the one I do want to allow.

UDFBLRESM
100011000

Now break this up into three groups of three numbers.  100 011 000 and
convert each group of three numbers to decimal.  100 = 4 in decimal. 
011 = 3 in decimal.  and 000 = 0 in decimal.

Now put those numbers together and you get 430

So to search for RUL only moves type "430" then a space then the cube
position.  I also like to do RULM moves which is 431 by the same process.

Now you have to input the cube state.  I'll input the T-orientation
case ZBLL alg that has all corners in the correct spot and the edges
are in the H permutation.

So UBR is rotated counter-clockwise, UBL is rotated clockwise, UF and
UB switch, and UR and UL switch.

In ACube this is:
UB UL UF UR !! ! -UBR +UBL !!

The edges are in the order UF UR UB UL DF DR DB DL FR FL BR BL
and the corners are in the order UFR UBR UBL UFL DFR DFL DBL DBR

The "!!" is short for everything past the last entry is in the correct
spot and oriented correctly.  A "!" means that single piece is solved
and oriented correclty.  Typing "!!" only goes through the end of that
type of piece.  So I have to type it once to say that all the
remaining corners are ok, and again at the end to say that all the
remaining edges are ok.

So UB UL UF UR !! ! -UBR +UBL !! is short for
UB UL UF UR DF DR DB DL FR FL BR BL UFR -UBR +UBL UFL DFR DFL DBL DBR

The "-" means that corner is rotated counter-clockwise and the "+"
means it is rotated clockwise.  A "-" in front of an edge means the
edges is flipped.

So to search for a RULM moves only solution to the above ZBLL case you
would type :
431 UB UL UF UR !! ! -UBR +UBL !!

Here are some useful face searches that I use a lot:
RUL = 430
RULM = 431
URF = 510
URLD = 630
URLF = 530
URFD = 710

Hope that helps some,
Chris

subject: COLL/EPLL or OLL/PLL for ZBLL cases you don't know?
content:
Hey everyone,

Ever since I started I've been using COLL/EPLL (edge PLL) for ZBLL
cases I don't know.  I think COLL/PLL is slower than OLL/PLL though,
so I've been working on that lately.

It's hard to get used to, but I think with time it will be faster. 
The problem is your chance for 1 look LL changes dramatically between
the two.

In order for a EPLL skip to count as non-lucky for speedcubing.com you
have to have a 20% or greater chance to skip the step you skipped.

For COLL/PLL the 1/12 chance to skip EPLL helps tremendously.  However
if you change that to the odds for OLL or PLL skip then things change.

Here are the numbers for how many ZBLL algs you have to know in order
to count your skips as non-lucky for COLL/PLL and OLL/PLL

COLL/PLL
(1/27) + (4/27)*(x/72) + (22/27)*(1/12) = 0.2
x = 46.2 or 47.

So you have to know basically 4 COLL cases and use all the PLL and
COLL/PLL on any case you don't know.

OLL/PLL
(1/27) + (4/27)*(x/72) + (22/27)*[(1/27)*(71/72) + (26/27)*(1/72) +
(1/27)*(1/72)] = 0.2

x = 59.24 or 60

So you have to know 60 ZBLL algs or 5 full COLL cases in order for
OLL/PLL step skip solves to be non-lucky for speedcubing.com

The only reason I say this is that you will start to get skip solves a
lot that are faster than your pb solves with Fridrich.  In order to
count those on speedcubing.com though, you have to use the above
strategies at the right time.

This assumes you know all ZBF2L.  At 4 COLL cases use COLL/PLL on
*every* ZBLL case you don't know and any skip solve that was
previously lucky now counts for speedcubing.com lists.

After 5 full COLL cases you can use OLL/PLL on any COLL case you don't
know and still have your skip solves count for speedcubing.com

Just some ways to stay motivated along the way :-D

So benchmark #1 is 4 COLL cases to have non lucky skip step solves. 
Then benchmark #2 is to get to 5 COLL cases so that you can switch to
OLL/PLL which is faster, and still have skip step solves non-lucky.

Chris

subject: Re: ZBLL averages
content:
--- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@h...> wrote:
>
> Yeah I think that's a good point.  For my slowest ZBLL cases I would
> also look at the COLL/PLL case and see if it was fast.  I never did
> try the OLL/PLL case though.  I think I'm going to look into that for
> my really slow ZBLL cases.
> 
> As long as OLL/PLL is faster than any other traditional style ZBLL alg
> I can find, then I would have no problem with using OLL/PLL (or maybe
> even COLL/PLL) for that case.
> 
> I just want to use the fastest option for each case, no matter what
> that is.
> 
> Chris

But, for all intents and purposes, knowing which ZB case you'll get,
then performing the OLL and PLL you've determined to be faster,
wouldn't it just be a different way to do the ZB case?
> 
> --- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@y...>
> wrote:
> >
> >      Fewest moves doesn't necessarily mean fastest times, so the
> average for zb will be around 13-14, yep.  And the oll/pll situation
> is not as rare as you think. :)  Nonetheless, the problem still exists.
> > -Brent M

I realize there will not always be faster times with ZB, but I think
the potential for ZB is greater than that of Fridrich.  Sure, the
recognition time will be slightly more, but there's only one
recognition period.  For OLL/PLL, there are two.  If you can keep the
single one with ZB reasonably short, combined with the potential for
fewer moves, I think it's a winning combination.

Certainly, shorter algs are not necessarily faster ones; the T perm is
one of my faster algs.  But with as much optimization as Chris is
putting into them, I really don't think it's going to be anywhere near
a problem.  I see sub 15 easily acheivable for him relatively soon.

-Mike

subject: Fixing corner orientation and/or permutaion
content:
With the last c/e pair, I often attempt to influence my corner
orientation on some of the simpler c/e cases.

For example, from Chris' list, the first and some other assorted cases
from groups 1, 6, and 13, I would see if any U turns I could perform
before or during insertion would grant me a better corner orientation
(which comes in mighty useful considering I only know one alg from the
Bruno COLL case at present).

I was curious what the odds of OLL skips after ZBF2L change to when
you only use these cases and what they are like after accounting for
trying to fix corners.

I'm also curious how difficult it would be to try to always fix corner
permutation during the last pair.  Certainly, it would add a lot of
algs, whether memorized or intuitive, to the ZBF2L plate, but it would
drastically reduce the number of necessary ZBLL algs.  As someone who
is planning to learn all only the ZB algs for correctly permuted
corners (and perhaps a few other special cases), this seems very
appealing.

I'm just looking for someone else's take on the idea, because I don't
recall anyone ever mentioning it before.  I'm highly interested in
learning more about this, if it can prove at all useful and manageable.

-Mike

subject: Re: Fixing corner orientation and/or permutaion
content:
Hey Mike,

(see comments below)

> With the last c/e pair, I often attempt to influence my corner
> orientation on some of the simpler c/e cases.
> 
> For example, from Chris' list, the first and some other assorted cases
> from groups 1, 6, and 13, I would see if any U turns I could perform
> before or during insertion would grant me a better corner orientation
> (which comes in mighty useful considering I only know one alg from the
> Bruno COLL case at present).
> 
> I was curious what the odds of OLL skips after ZBF2L change to when
> you only use these cases and what they are like after accounting for
> trying to fix corners.

I really like trying to work out odds and scenarios.  I don't think I
fully understand what you are doing yet, but I'd love to try to work
out the odds for you.  Do you mean that you still do a ZBF2L (flip all
LL edges correctly after having solved the last c/e pair) and in
addition orient some or all of the corners?  Would you make sure that
you have say at least 1, or at least 2, or all corners solved?

> 
> I'm also curious how difficult it would be to try to always fix corner
> permutation during the last pair.  Certainly, it would add a lot of
> algs, whether memorized or intuitive, to the ZBF2L plate, but it would
> drastically reduce the number of necessary ZBLL algs.  As someone who
> is planning to learn all only the ZB algs for correctly permuted
> corners (and perhaps a few other special cases), this seems very
> appealing.


What about this, you could learn all the algs to both orient edges and
place all corners for ZBF2L case 1 and 13.

I imagine for each ZBF2L case there would be around 12 algs not
including reflections that you would need to also move corners.

So for 16 cases you would need 12 for each of them so that's 192 algs
for ZBF2L (a little more than full ZBF2L) but it would reduce your
ZBLL count to the ones with just correct corners (84 I believe).

That would take fewer algs than ZB, and I imagine it would be pretty
fast.  For F2L on the last c/e pair you could either pair up the
corner and edge or form them into case 13, then use the required alg
to flip edge, permute corners, and solve the c/e pair.  Then you would
have 84 possibilities for the truncated ZBLL solve.

I think it would lose a little bit of time off regular ZB by having to
either form case 1 or case 13 with the corner and edge (max 5-6 moves
I would guess?  maybe 7 moves on a very very small number of cases). 
The recognition for the extended ZBF2L would be a bit longer than
regular ZBF2L as well.

So the only time you add is maybe an extra second for recognition,
plus .75-1.0 seconds for forming the pair.  I believe with mastery of
ZBF2L that sub-14 is possible for ZB, so with an extra up to 2 seconds
you could expect this method to average 15 seconds?  Myabe even sub-15
with good cases over the average?

I think it shouldn't lose much time off regular ZB, and it requires
far fewer cases to learn.  I think the method seems sound personally.

Chris

> 
> I'm just looking for someone else's take on the idea, because I don't
> recall anyone ever mentioning it before.  I'm highly interested in
> learning more about this, if it can prove at all useful and manageable.
> 
> -Mike
>

subject: Re: Fixing corner orientation and/or permutaion
content:
--- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@h...> wrote:

Thanks for the reply. You should have started this group a long time
ago. :)

> (see comments below)

> I really like trying to work out odds and scenarios.  I don't think I
> fully understand what you are doing yet, but I'd love to try to work
> out the odds for you.  Do you mean that you still do a ZBF2L (flip all
> LL edges correctly after having solved the last c/e pair) and in
> addition orient some or all of the corners?  Would you make sure that
> you have say at least 1, or at least 2, or all corners solved?

As a quick example, set up this on a solved cube:

R U2 R' U

Instead of the normal R U'R, I'd do the inverse of the setup.  I can
only do this to cases where a single or double U turn fixes them.

However, because I don't know the Bruno COLL cases, and I've only just
learned the Double Sune cases, it's very helpful to see when the LL
corners will come out all incorrectly oriented, and be able to switch
them to a different case.  Most times, if I can't get a full OLL skip
out of it, I can at least transform into either the L or T shapes,
which all of my algs for are very fast.  Again, this generally only
adds 2 or so turns to a solve, and gives a much better LL.
 
> > 
> > I'm also curious how difficult it would be to try to always fix corner
> > permutation during the last pair.  Certainly, it would add a lot of
> > algs, whether memorized or intuitive, to the ZBF2L plate, but it would
> > drastically reduce the number of necessary ZBLL algs.  As someone who
> > is planning to learn all only the ZB algs for correctly permuted
> > corners (and perhaps a few other special cases), this seems very
> > appealing.
> 
> 
> What about this, you could learn all the algs to both orient edges and
> place all corners for ZBF2L case 1 and 13.
> 
> I imagine for each ZBF2L case there would be around 12 algs not
> including reflections that you would need to also move corners.
> 
> So for 16 cases you would need 12 for each of them so that's 192 algs
> for ZBF2L (a little more than full ZBF2L) but it would reduce your
> ZBLL count to the ones with just correct corners (84 I believe).

I'm trying now to figure out how exactly to do this.  I've realized
that simple U turns alone can't accomplish this, because they leave
the corner permutation unaffected, only changing the orientation.  I
know there should be a simple way to do this, but I can't for the life
of me figure out how.

> 
> That would take fewer algs than ZB, and I imagine it would be pretty
> fast.  For F2L on the last c/e pair you could either pair up the
> corner and edge or form them into case 13, then use the required alg
> to flip edge, permute corners, and solve the c/e pair.  Then you would
> have 84 possibilities for the truncated ZBLL solve.
> 
> I think it would lose a little bit of time off regular ZB by having to
> either form case 1 or case 13 with the corner and edge (max 5-6 moves
> I would guess?  maybe 7 moves on a very very small number of cases). 
> The recognition for the extended ZBF2L would be a bit longer than
> regular ZBF2L as well.
> 
> So the only time you add is maybe an extra second for recognition,
> plus .75-1.0 seconds for forming the pair.  I believe with mastery of
> ZBF2L that sub-14 is possible for ZB, so with an extra up to 2 seconds
> you could expect this method to average 15 seconds?  Myabe even sub-15
> with good cases over the average?
> 
> I think it shouldn't lose much time off regular ZB, and it requires
> far fewer cases to learn.  I think the method seems sound personally.

Sub-15 or perhaps below sounds amazing to me, as I'm still thrilled
with a slightly sub-20 average.  Even with all of ZBF2L, I don't think
I could achieve that with simple COLL/EPLL alone.  If there's a way to
make this work, I'm willing to try.

I just need to know how to make the darn thing work first...

-Mike

subject: My Progress (ZBF2L)
content:
Hey all,

Here is a small update on my progress:

According to Chris's page, I know the following cases:
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, and half of 6.  I can do #13 using VH, but I haven't

I will let everybody know when I post the new page.

~ Bob

subject: [zbmethod] how to start with zb ?
content:
Hello,

I'm kind of thinking to learn that system for the LL.
However, I have a few question :

Is it better to learn first the ZB-LL or the ZB-F2L ?
I'm kind of thinking that it would be better to start with the ZB-LL
and use it only when I have that OLL.
But I would like your advices first. :-)

Also, about the alg, should I use ACube to find some alg if the ones
already displayed on the net don't "fit" with me ?

Thanks :-)
Gilles.

subject: Re: ACube
content:
Ok, Thanks!! i tell you if works!

Santiago

www.speedcubing.com.ar


--- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@h...> wrote:
>
> Hey Santiago,
> 
> What I do is this.  Open up the command window by clicking 
on "start",
> then "run", then type in "command" and click on "OK"
> 
> If you don't use windows then get to a place where you can run a 
java
> program from a command screen.
> 
> In the windows command program you have to change directories to 
where
> your files are for ACube using the tradional DOS directory commands.
> 
> Once you get to the right directory, type in this
> 
> java -cp ACube3.jar ACube
> 
> Now after that line you have a few options for attributes.  You can
> have the program search in either face turn metric, slice turn 
metric,
> or quarter turn metric.  Your other options are to search for 
optimal
> length algs or algs of any length, and also for the program to print
> out every alg it finds or only a small portion.
> 
> The commands I use to search for ZBLL algs are these:
> 
> java -cp ACube3.jar ACube q a
> 
> The "q" means to search in quartern turn metrics and the "a" means
> print out every single alg.
> 
> Once I've analyzed the positions in that metric I exit the program
> with "Ctrl + C" and start it again with
> 
> java -cp ACube3.jar ACube a
> 
> This searches in face turn metric (face turn is the default) and
> prints out every alg it finds.
> 
> I then compare the best quarter turn algs and best face turn algs 
and
> try to find the best alg among those.  If you are comfortable with
> slice moves, which I am not, then you would also want to use this
> search string
> 
> java -cp ACube3.jar ACube s a
> 
> --------------
> 
> Once in ACube you have to decide which types of turns you want to
> allow, and you have to input the position.
> 
> While in quarter turn searching (java -cp ACube3.jar ACube q a) I
> often start with searching for [RUL] only algs.  To do this I have 
to
> come up with the octet that represents R U and L only.
> 
> The order of the faces is UDFBLRESM
> 
> I only want to allow R U and L so I would go through and put a "0" 
on
> the face I don't want to allow and a "1" on the one I do want to 
allow.
> 
> UDFBLRESM
> 100011000
> 
> Now break this up into three groups of three numbers.  100 011 000 
and
> convert each group of three numbers to decimal.  100 = 4 in 
decimal. 
> 011 = 3 in decimal.  and 000 = 0 in decimal.
> 
> Now put those numbers together and you get 430
> 
> So to search for RUL only moves type "430" then a space then the 
cube
> position.  I also like to do RULM moves which is 431 by the same 
process.
> 
> Now you have to input the cube state.  I'll input the T-orientation
> case ZBLL alg that has all corners in the correct spot and the edges
> are in the H permutation.
> 
> So UBR is rotated counter-clockwise, UBL is rotated clockwise, UF 
and
> UB switch, and UR and UL switch.
> 
> In ACube this is:
> UB UL UF UR !! ! -UBR +UBL !!
> 
> The edges are in the order UF UR UB UL DF DR DB DL FR FL BR BL
> and the corners are in the order UFR UBR UBL UFL DFR DFL DBL DBR
> 
> The "!!" is short for everything past the last entry is in the 
correct
> spot and oriented correctly.  A "!" means that single piece is 
solved
> and oriented correclty.  Typing "!!" only goes through the end of 
that
> type of piece.  So I have to type it once to say that all the
> remaining corners are ok, and again at the end to say that all the
> remaining edges are ok.
> 
> So UB UL UF UR !! ! -UBR +UBL !! is short for
> UB UL UF UR DF DR DB DL FR FL BR BL UFR -UBR +UBL UFL DFR DFL DBL 
DBR
> 
> The "-" means that corner is rotated counter-clockwise and the "+"
> means it is rotated clockwise.  A "-" in front of an edge means the
> edges is flipped.
> 
> So to search for a RULM moves only solution to the above ZBLL case 
you
> would type :
> 431 UB UL UF UR !! ! -UBR +UBL !!
> 
> Here are some useful face searches that I use a lot:
> RUL = 430
> RULM = 431
> URF = 510
> URLD = 630
> URLF = 530
> URFD = 710
> 
> Hope that helps some,
> Chris
> 
> --- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, "Santiago" <hiei_jaganshi_333@y...>
> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Chris, i'm new at this, can you tell me how work the ACube?? i 
> > don't know how too use it, and the txt file doesn't help me. 
Thanks
> > 
> > Santiago from Argentina
> > 
> > www.speedcubing.com.ar
> >
>

subject: Re: [zbmethod] Advantages of ZBF2L
content:
I'm still wondering if the zb method is really worth it.

I mean, it's just another way so solve the LL in 2 looks with a more
complicated recognition.
I think the only way to really improve the Fridrich system is to start
learning the LL in one alg.
That, as I see it, would be a very interesting improvement.
That's why I'm thinking learning the ZB-LL as the first step of the LL
in one look.
There are not so many cases after all.
If you want to learn the ZB-F2L, you could learn some other patterns
to solve them in one alg.

This is still a possibility and I don't know if I'm really going to
learn the complete LL in one look (over 5.000 cases) but I think the
ZB-LL is very useful.

Well, maybe tomorrow morning when I'll re-read this message I'll see
that I'm actually completely tired, but I think this makes sense.

What do you think ?
Gilles.

2005/11/11, Chris Hunt <huntca@...>:
> Howdy guys,
>
> Does ZBF2L really give you an advantage over a Fridrich F2L solve? I was
> thinking that the entire ZB solve would still result in two 'looks', so it
> seems as though it would be the same as OLL/PLL except you're doing ZBF2L,
> then ZBLL. You would solve the first three pairs, then recognize the ZBF2L
> case (OLL), then recognize the ZBLL case (PLL).
>
> It makes more sense to me to learn as many ZBLL cases as you can so that you
> can finish the F2L with basic Fridrich and then solve the last layer in one
> look.
>
> It would be a lot easier to recognize the OLL/PLL then it would for the
> ZBF2L/ZBLL case, would it not?
>
> I'm just wondering what the advantage of ZB would be over Fridrich. You
> still need to recognize two cases, which seem harder to recognize than
> OLL/PLL.
>
> I'm really interested in 'stepping up' my game, so I'm trying to figure out
> what would help me the most.
>
> I'm sorry if this is worded poorly, but I had to write it quickly to get to
> class :)
>
> -Chris

subject: Re: Advantages of ZBF2L
content:
Look at things this way:

ZBF2L really only adds a few moves to most of your solves, and none to
several.

ZBLL shortens the number of moves for your LL on average.

If you could learn full ZB, you should be able to average 45 moves or
less.

Fridrich takes around 55 on average, I think.

That's 10 moves, or 2-4 seconds potentially it could save, assuming
you have quick recognition.

-Mike Bennett

subject: Re: Advantages of ZBF2L
content:
My claim is that ZBF2L, with "enough" practice, will require the same
amount of recognition as the 4th normal Fridrich F2L pair.  The
question is:  "what is 'enough' practice?" Nobody yet knows the
answer.... that is, unless chris has some sort of idea?

~ Bob

subject: Re: Advantages of ZBF2L
content:
I can't really see how learning 1-look LL is better then learning full ZB. With a 1-look LL:

* the averge number of moves to solve the complete cube is about the same as with full ZB 
(about 47 moves).
* you would have to learn about 8 times the amount of algorihtms (3915 vesus 798). 
* recognition would be much tougher since with ZB you spread the work more evenly over 
the last couple of steps.

So it seems to me that you're doing much more work to safe exactly the same amount of 
moves and time. What are others people opinions on this? 

Going back to Chris' point on ZBF2L/ZBLL "replacing" OLL/PLL but being more 
complicated: that's true, but:
* any recognition task that is or can be mastered to perfection will in the end become 
instantaneous and just as fast as an easier recognition task. This just requires practice.
* Looking at it this way, you sort of skip the 4th pair and immediately start doing ZBF2L 
which gives you a signifcant advantage in terms of move count.

I'm still very convinced that ZB is the best Fridrich extension that people have come up 
with so far. Any other idea I've heard so far (and I've heard many), either don't give as 
much advantage lengthwise and just makes your method more complicated, or either give 
the same advantage as ZB but require much more learning in the end (Gilles' idea being a 
good example).

I understand why people get discouraged by the number of algorithms you have to learn, 
but think about how ominous Fridrich seemed when you first learned about it (it certainly 
was for me!). Although ZB has much more cases, you already have so much expierence 
from learning your current system that you can rely on and that you can use as a leverage 
for learning ZB.

There's only one way to find out if ZB is worth it: try it!

Lars

subject: Re: Advantages of ZBF2L
content:
Yeah, that's correct.  Using COLL, you have a 8/12 chance of getting a
3 edge cycle, 2/12 chance of getting a Z perm, 1/12 chance of a cross
perm, and 1/12 chance of a PLL skip.  Recognition will slow you down
at first, but with some practice I've found COLL to be pretty helpful
most of the time.

-Jason

subject: Re: Advantages of ZBF2L
content:
> --- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, Chris Hunt <huntca@g...> wrote:
> >
> > Good points Lars. I'm very interested in learning ZB and I'm going
> to start
> > learning COLL. I'm very behind everyone else in this group :)
> > 
> > I think I remeber someone here saying (was that you Chris?) that
> with ZBF2L
> > and COLL that you have a 1/12 chance of the edges being solved as
> well (PLL
> > skip). Is this true? If so, then I think COLL will be very useful
> for me to
> > start learning!
> > 
> > -Chris

Yes.  In fact, you really only need to know the case 1 and case 13
ZBF2L algs in order to get these kind of skip chances.

As for the COLL algs, they're great.  Just make sure to find ones that
fit you.  The same goes for recognition.  I think everyone else here
uses the sticker method, which boggles my mind and hurts my brain, and
I just use the simple 'see which corners need to switch' method.  It's
up to you, but I bet you can guess which I think is better...

-Mike

subject: Re: Advantages of ZBF2L
content:
Oh, come on!  Using the sticker method, you can tell which ones need
to be swapped just by looking at the top face sometimes! (Sune,
Antisune, Bruno, and H)

~ Bob

subject: Re: Fixing corner orientation and/or permutaion
content:
--- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...>
wrote:

> > (see comments below)

> 
> As a quick example, set up this on a solved cube:
> 
> R U2 R' U
> 
> Instead of the normal R U'R, I'd do the inverse of the setup.  I can
> only do this to cases where a single or double U turn fixes them.

Oops. That should be R U2 R' U'.

Anyway, I'm getting much better at fixing or altering corner
orientation with the last F2L pair.  Right now, I can really only use
it to fix similar cases to the above, and to change cases with four
incorrectly oriented corners to cases with fewer (which I know
better).  I know that there are simple ways to expand upon this, such
as the setup RU2R'U'RUR'U'.  You can fix it with the inverse, which is
very quick.  I know there are probably similar ways to speed up other
cases, but I haven't tried to find any yet.

Using this, I managed an 18.40 average earlier, beating my previous
best average by almost 1 second.  I don't know if there are more cases
it's easy to fix this way, but I'm curious what the odds to skip the
OLL step entirely improve to.  I'm wondering if anything more than
what I'm using already is worthwhile in terms of moves or time saved.

I know that without this, the odds are something like 1/27, or ~3.7%.
 Added to the 1/12 (8.33%)chance for skipping PLL, that's just over
12% chances for a skipped step every solve.  I know this improves the
odds slightly, but I'd like to know how much.

If anyone has any ideas on how to fix corner permutation instead I'd
like to hear them, as well.

-Mike

subject: Team [zb]
content:
Hey everyone,

So I know the french guys have been doing team absolut for a while,
and competing against eachother and helping eachother has clearly done
wonders for their times.

Well Bob Burton and I were talking and we think maybe a team [zb]
could do the same for us.

Here is the proposal.  We all invade the sunday contest every sunday,
and we use however much zb techniques we know.  This is great practice
to time yourself with the new techniques.  I mean go all out, make
mistakes, try new things with the timer still going, etc.

I've found that knowing ZBLL and ZBF2L and speedsolving ZBLL and ZBF2L
are two entirely different things, so I think starting early on timing
would be a good thing.

Also, this would be a good chance for us to motivate eachother to
learn more.  We can share tips afterward, talk through solves on this
group etc..

Also having people see our progress on the sunday contest over time
may motivate others to try.

So remember, if you want to work on your zb, do the sunday contest and
at the end of your quote but something [zb] or ZB or whatever to show
that is what you used.

Bob and I will be doing this for this week's sunday contest and we
would love for everyone to join in!

Use whatever you know, even if it's no much!  This is a chance to try
out your new algs!

Hope to see you all there,
Chris

subject: Re: Team [zb]
content:

http://www.geocities.com/nascarjon2001/sunday.htm#scrambles

Chris

some amnesia and other fun things (one solve we both did the wrong
zbf2l!) :-D  It was a lot of fun!  Let's try to organize the group to
do the sunday contest every week.  We can make a weekly sunday chat
and do the average whenever you have time to stop by.

Well I hope this takes off, I think it will do wonder for our times.

Team [zb]
Chris

subject: Re: Team [zb]
content:
Ya there is a huge difference between knowing it and speedsolving
with it. I can definitely attest to that.

Just to introduce myself here a bit. I have been using ideas from 
the ZB method for roughly 2.5 years now. I started speeedsolving 
about 6 years ago with CLL/ELL and my own F2L system after having 
spent a lot of time finding CLL and ELL algs (about a year). At that 
time I didn't know about the speedsolving community and my times 
where around 90s.

Three years ago I finished learning the COLL set (this was before it 
was called COLL). Around the same time I started learning the ZBLL 
cases for no corner permutation (1/6 chance of running into this).

I am a relatively slow solver, averaging 22.30 (a non-RA I did last 
week). I am learning the ZBLL by Corner Permutation category (and 
CLL sub-categories). I get a 1-look LL about 45% of the time now.

Off Chris's ZBF2L page, I know cases 1,2,3,5,13 and a bit of 4,6,7. 
The reason I get so many 1-look LL is because I know multiple CLL's 
for each CLL case. Also I do some more advanced stuff during F2L, 
such as flipping edges on 3rd c/e pair; choosing which of the last 
two to do as my 3rd pair; and knowing a set of algorithms for 
partial cross solving. That is availible here:
http://www-personal.umich.edu/~dlli/NewAlgSet.html
after RichardP requested it.

I am working on multiple things now. Learning ZBF2L cases 4,6,7; 
geting better at regonizing ZBLL cases in the Sune category; and 
mastering the alg set given above (I have a couple more to go).


-Doug

subject: First sub 20 average using VH!
content:
Hi guys,

I just got my first sub 20 using the VH system!

22.65, 18.56, 18.89, 17.36, (25.37), 17.46, 22.28, 20.22, 19.22,
20.76, (17.00), 22.41 ==> 19.98

The 17.46 was a PLL skip using COLL, and on the 18.89 I used ZBLL
(took a while to recall it though!).  For all of these solves I had to
convert the fourth pair into either a pair and instert case or just an
insert case.  I was really not expecting this because previously my
best average with this method was 22.xx.  To top it off, this was for
the Sunday Contest!

On a side note, how many ZB algs do I have to know until I can say I
use ZB and not VH?

I'm feeling very good about this method right now.  I think that once
I know more of it, I'll be getting some very nice times!  :P

-Jason
team [zb]

subject: Definition of VH system.
content: [ Attachment content not displayed ]

subject: Re: Definition of VH system.
content:
Hi Chris,

You have it right except for the 4th pair.  VHF2L is done in two
steps.  First, you pair up the fourth pair.  Then, you insert it while
orienting LL edges.  I'm not sure if the pair+insert cases count as
VHF2L or ZBF2L, though.  But yeah, VH is basically just a simplified
form of the ZB method.

-Jason

--- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, Chris Hunt <huntca@g...> wrote:
>
> Although not ZB, I thought this might be related because it is my belief
> that both these systems orient the edges of the LL while simultaneously
> placing the final pair.
> 
> I looked somewhere for a formal definition of the VH system and couldn't
> find it! Please let me know if I understand the VH system correctly:
> 
> 1) Cross
> 2) 3 F2L pairs
> 3) 4th pair, while orienting LL edges at the same time
> 4) Finish with COLL and EPLL, or just PLL if the corners are already
> oriented correctly.
> 
> Is this correct? If so, I guess it makes sense to learn VH and then
move to
> ZB.
> 
> -Chris
>

subject: Re: Team [zb]
content:
I'm using all but one of the COLL algs, partial edge control and some
corner control on top of that, and a few ZB cases for corners
correctly permuted.  My average was 21.37, because of a few very slow
COLL cases.  Also, I didn't manage any PLL skips, and only my first
solve did I get an easy OLL skip with corner control.

Anyway, I can't seem to find any decent algs for the Bruno case with
all four corners permuted incorrectly.  I tend to favor algs in the
LUR group, and sometimes ones with F turns in them.  All of the sites
I've looked at use the same alg that doesn't work for me, and Ron's
cube solver couldn't find any solutions of decent length.  If anyone
has any suggestions, I'd like to hear them.  I keep getting this alg
in practice and it's incredibly slow to do it in two steps.

-Mike

content:
Conceivably, if you could learn how to orient all corners after fixing
the edges for every case, that narrows your LL following that to the
PLL cases.  I imagine the number of algs for this to be something like
24 x 2 x 2 cases, for both the reflections and the case 1 and 13 edge
orienting algs.

This leaves us with 96 algs and our LL is reduced to the PLL.

Any thoughts?

-Mike

subject: Re: Team [zb]
content:
Old habit, I always called it the Bruno. In it's pure form it is 
the "4 corners" (4 courners twisted but not the "double-superman"), 
no CP and a specific 3 edge cycle.

To me Bruno=R' U2 R2 U R2 U R2 U2 R'.

It goes by the names in team BLD as "The Wheel", "Four Corners" 
and "Pie". I think these 4 terms are pretty standard now.

It can be extended to include all the ones in that COLL case (those 
w/o CP). Or it can be extended to what DanH, Hardwick (I think), and 
I call the Pi-Orientation. It's all the ZBLL cases with all 4 
corners twisted (the less symmetric of the two).

It really depends on the context. However I'd prefer it to be stated 
clearly as there seems to be confusion frequently.

-Doug

subject: Intuitive vs. Concrete
content:
I've been doing a lot of thinking, now that I've learned all of my
COLL and have begun tackling ZBF2L in earnest, and a lot of it has
centered on whether it's better to use an intuitive or rigid approach
to ZBF2L.

Both have their benefits:

Rigid approach probably affords faster recognition and execution. 
This can lead to great times.  Chris Hardwick is a testament to this.

Intuitive approach makes for less to learn, helps you understand the
way the cube works more so you get less amnesia, and allows you to
optimize on the fly.

I think throughout ZBF2L, I'm going to try to learn as many algorithms
intuitively as possible, because I like the benefits more.  I can
perform many of them from more than one angle, and I can often fix or
influence corner orientation along the way.

Is anyone else attempting to learn algs like this, or does everyone
try to learn the cases, rather than what's going on with the cube?

-Mike

P.S.  Where has our fearless leader been?  Some of us are eagerly
awaiting replies. ;)

subject: Re: [zbmethod] Intuitive vs. Concrete
content: [ Attachment content not displayed ]

subject: Re: Intuitive vs. Concrete
content:
I memorize the ZBF2L cases intuitively. There really aren't that 
many algs in my arsenal that I don't understand and apply blindly. 
I'd like to keep it that way.

When learning a ZBF2L alg, I'll disect it into parts: if it's a 
conjugator, if it messes with a cross edge, if it transforms it into 
another ZBF2L case... etc.

I also know all the secondary effects of my COLL algs. So I pick 
between doing it or it's mirror depending on edges.


-Doug

subject: Re: Intuitive vs. Concrete
content:
Hey everyone,

I'm still working on a page that shows the most common ZBF2L patterns.
 Quite often a few cases are really just one underlying short case,
with setup moves into it.

That will be up shortly, I just need to find time around my homework,
of which unfortunately there is a lot :-(

As far as intuitive vs. concrete, I guess I have always been in the
conrete camp on anything new, maybe the 4x4 is the only exception
where I try to discover new things on my own.

I tend to be too impatient, and would rather learn it all and recall
from memory, then over time come to understand.

That is just my laziness to be perfectly honest, I think intuitive
zbf2l would ultimately be faster.  I can only hope that after a year
when you guys all know intuitive zbf2l second nature that I can hope
to keep up :-P

Anyway, I think intuitive learning is a very good idea, and my page to
help with that will hopefully be done very shortly.

Chris
team [zb]

subject: A Lot of Progress
content:
Tonight I finished learning ZBF2l Case #7 and Case #10. A couple 
hours later after doing other things, I quized myself on each one 
randomly and got em.

I also double checked that I can do all the Case 4 and 5 that I 
learned the previous day.

Most notably however I think I got to the 25% mark on the S-
Orientation (or S and AS combined). Tonight I spent a few hours 
trying to make sure I can do recognition for these cases. I'm sure 
Chris would agree that these are the hardest to recognize cases in 
ZBLL.

The bulk of it were all the ones that had no CP. There are dozens of 
cases here alone if you count mirrors and inverses. Outside of no 
CP, I learned 2 cases for each Sunish-COLL.

I just spent an additional 30 minutes after taking a shower to quiz 
myself on these S-Ori with no CP ones. I think I can actively use 
them in my speedsolving now. Recognition is now pretty comfortable.

Ok my eyes really, really hurt now.


-Doug

subject: Re: A Lot of Progress
content:
Due to some miraculous miracle, I passed another quizing this 
morning. Rentention is not so bad once you try to incorporate the 
algs into your regular solving. It slows me down a bit though, but I 
know it's only temporary.

-Doug

subject: Re: Intuitive vs. Concrete
content:
Actually, it is only the "bad" cases that take "much" longer.  And of
course, "much" is relative. ;)  In particular, think about a paired-up
edge and flipping all 4 edges before placing it.  This is a VH
worst-case scenerio at about 13 moves, but there is a nice 7-move alg
that does this in 7.

~ Bob

> ~ Bob
> 
> --- In zbmethod@...m, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote:
> >
> > I already learned the basic intuition for ZBF2L, so now I am learning
> > the algs so that I spend less time recognizing and can use the (MUCH)
> > shorter algorithms to do what I need.
> > 
> > ~ Bob
> > Team [zb]
> > 
> > --- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...>
> > wrote:
> > >
> > > I've been doing a lot of thinking, now that I've learned all of my
> > > COLL and have begun tackling ZBF2L in earnest, and a lot of it has
> > > centered on whether it's better to use an intuitive or rigid
approach
> > > to ZBF2L.
> > > 
> > > Both have their benefits:
> > > 
> > > Rigid approach probably affords faster recognition and execution. 
> > > This can lead to great times.  Chris Hardwick is a testament to
this.
> > > 
> > > Intuitive approach makes for less to learn, helps you understand the
> > > way the cube works more so you get less amnesia, and allows you to
> > > optimize on the fly.
> > > 
> > > I think throughout ZBF2L, I'm going to try to learn as many
algorithms
> > > intuitively as possible, because I like the benefits more.  I can
> > > perform many of them from more than one angle, and I can often
fix or
> > > influence corner orientation along the way.
> > > 
> > > Is anyone else attempting to learn algs like this, or does everyone
> > > try to learn the cases, rather than what's going on with the cube?
> > > 
> > > -Mike
> > > 
> > > P.S.  Where has our fearless leader been?  Some of us are eagerly
> > > awaiting replies. ;)
> > >
> >
>

subject: One more reason I like ZB so much
content:
Hey everyone,

I'm really going to being in earnest with this "one parity" method for
the 4x4x4.  Bascailly it entails using the COLL case to identify
whether or not your have double parity or just single parity whenever
you see the OLL parity.

I'm going to complete all the orientation pages and COLL images on my
ZBLL page in order to use it as a study aid.

I will continue to only add the actual algorithms as I learn them.  I
really only post an alg once I know it through and through, so that
won't change.

If you're interested in this method, let me know and I can explain
more about it.  ZB is what gave me the idea to try it, and since
working out better solutions to the parity algs is the hot topic for
4x4x4 solving right now I want to pursue it pretty hard myself.

So ZB helps for other cubes, not just the 3x3x3.

The advantage to using the "one-parity" method is also that ZBLL
becomes a viable option on 4x4x4 since you can be certain of a true
ZBLL case without parity.

Something to think about if you're interested in using your new ZB
stuff to help for the larger cubes as well.

Chris
team [zb]

--- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@h...> wrote:
>
> Hey Santiago,
> 
> What I do is this. Open up the command window by clicking on "start",
> then "run", then type in "command" and click on "OK"
> 
> If you don't use windows then get to a place where you can run a java
> program from a command screen.
> 
> In the windows command program you have to change directories to where
> your files are for ACube using the tradional DOS directory commands.
> 
> Once you get to the right directory, type in this
> 
> java -cp ACube3.jar ACube
> 
> Now after that line you have a few options for attributes. You can
> have the program search in either face turn metric, slice turn metric,
> or quarter turn metric. Your other options are to search for optimal
> length algs or algs of any length, and also for the program to print
> out every alg it finds or only a small portion.
> 
> The commands I use to search for ZBLL algs are these:
> 
> java -cp ACube3.jar ACube q a
> 
> The "q" means to search in quartern turn metrics and the "a" means
> print out every single alg.
> 
> Once I've analyzed the positions in that metric I exit the program
> with "Ctrl + C" and start it again with
> 
> java -cp ACube3.jar ACube a
> 
> This searches in face turn metric (face turn is the default) and
> prints out every alg it finds.
> 
> I then compare the best quarter turn algs and best face turn algs and
> try to find the best alg among those. If you are comfortable with
> slice moves, which I am not, then you would also want to use this
> search string
> 
> java -cp ACube3.jar ACube s a
> 
> --------------
> 
> Once in ACube you have to decide which types of turns you want to
> allow, and you have to input the position.
> 
> While in quarter turn searching (java -cp ACube3.jar ACube q a) I
> often start with searching for [RUL] only algs. To do this I have to
> come up with the octet that represents R U and L only.
> 
> The order of the faces is UDFBLRESM
> 
> I only want to allow R U and L so I would go through and put a "0" on
> the face I don't want to allow and a "1" on the one I do want to allow.
> 
> UDFBLRESM
> 100011000
> 
> Now break this up into three groups of three numbers. 100 011 000 and
> convert each group of three numbers to decimal. 100 = 4 in decimal. 
> 011 = 3 in decimal. and 000 = 0 in decimal.
> 
> Now put those numbers together and you get 430
> 
> So to search for RUL only moves type "430" then a space then the cube
> position. I also like to do RULM moves which is 431 by the same process.
> 
> Now you have to input the cube state. I'll input the T-orientation
> case ZBLL alg that has all corners in the correct spot and the edges
> are in the H permutation.
> 
> So UBR is rotated counter-clockwise, UBL is rotated clockwise, UF and
> UB switch, and UR and UL switch.
> 
> In ACube this is:
> UB UL UF UR !! ! -UBR +UBL !!
> 
> The edges are in the order UF UR UB UL DF DR DB DL FR FL BR BL
> and the corners are in the order UFR UBR UBL UFL DFR DFL DBL DBR
> 
> The "!!" is short for everything past the last entry is in the correct
> spot and oriented correctly. A "!" means that single piece is solved
> and oriented correclty. Typing "!!" only goes through the end of that
> type of piece. So I have to type it once to say that all the
> remaining corners are ok, and again at the end to say that all the
> remaining edges are ok.
> 
> So UB UL UF UR !! ! -UBR +UBL !! is short for
> UB UL UF UR DF DR DB DL FR FL BR BL UFR -UBR +UBL UFL DFR DFL DBL DBR
> 
> The "-" means that corner is rotated counter-clockwise and the "+"
> means it is rotated clockwise. A "-" in front of an edge means the
> edges is flipped.
> 
> So to search for a RULM moves only solution to the above ZBLL case you
> would type :
> 431 UB UL UF UR !! ! -UBR +UBL !!
> 
> Here are some useful face searches that I use a lot:
> RUL = 430
> RULM = 431
> URF = 510
> URLD = 630
> URLF = 530
> URFD = 710
> 
> Hope that helps some,
> Chris
> 
> --- In zbmethod@yahoogroups.com, "Santiago" hiei_jaganshi_333@y...
> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Chris, i'm new at this, can you tell me how work the ACube?? i 
> > don't know how too use it, and the txt file doesn't help me. Thanks
> > 
> > Santiago from Argentina
> > 
> > www.speedcubing.com.ar
> >
>

subject: 11/13/05 Sunday contest
content:
Hey everyone,

We had six team [zb] solvers in the sunday contest!  This is totally
cool!  Congrats to everyone who used ZB, and I hope you were able to
learn something new, or cement your new cases a little better!

I really do think competing once a week like this will help us all to
really not only learn this method, but learn to speedsolve with it. 
It will take work yes, but if we all motivate eachother I think the
time spent learning it can be quite fun!

Looking forward to using ZB with you all again this coming sunday! ;-)

Chris

subject: Re: One more reason I like ZB so much
content:
I am rather behind on the posts in the other forum.

I just read 
http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/20
694
and decided to open JNetCube and see how many it took me.

It gave me the following scramble:
B U' F' U F2 U' D2 L' B' L2 U' R' L2 U2 R2 F' U' R' D R B F' L' R' F

I was able to do F2L in 31 turns. Moreover it was ZBF2L. Even better 
was that I applied your idea of avoiding 4 twisted corners while 
still ZB-ing. It was a Case #1 so it was a bit trivial. I knew the 
ZBLL for that particular L-Orientation I got.

Total number of turns: 40!!!

Funny, my WC05 FMC qualifying was 51 :(.


-Doug

subject: Progress
content:
I think it'd be good if we all periodically post updates here about 
our progress.

So today I found that I am forgetting a couple of the Case 7 and 
Case 10's. But I'm only off by one move somewhere, so it should 
should be okay.

I worked on quizing myself on the S-Orientaion with no CP yesterday 
and I think I have them all down now. I have an interesting naming 
scheme for these guys if your interested.

I just did a sitting in which about half of my solves where 1-look 
LL. I did lag up a bit though.

The two algs I need to work on are the T2 with an F-ish perm, and 
the U2 with an F-ish perm.

Altogether, I know (and ACTIVELY USE!) 5 in T1, 6 in T2, 5 in U1, 
and 8 in U2. (I prefer to think of T1 and U1 as the same thing 
though.)

I average knowing 1.7 cases in each of the other COLL categories.

I also have all the H1, missing one L1, and about half the Pi1.

I think I won't learn anymore ZBF2L for a while, I don't want to 
confuse myself. (I know 1,2,3,4,5,7,10,13.)

I have yet to come across the S1 cases in speedsolving, so I hope to 
have fully incorporated these ZBLL into my solving by the end of the 
month. Then I'll move on... maybe finish Case 6 (2 of 6 I have been 
using for over a year so only 4 more there).

Where are you guys at?


-Doug

subject: Re: Progress
content:
I sadly have not been practicing as much as I should be lately.  I 
mostly just practice transformation solves (transform whatever OLL I 
get after ZBF2L into "T") and I haven't timed myself with ZB since 
the sunday contest.

Lately 4x4x4 BLD has consumed all of my free time, big cubes BLD is 
a drug lol, be wary ;-)

I still remember all of my T algs, though I delay recognizing my T6 
cases and about half of my T5's still :-(

I still know my U1 cases and the half of U2 that I know.  I need to 
decide on an alg for my next two cases and I should soon finish up 
U2.

School has been kicking my butt lately :-( so I haven't been as 
diligent as I should be right now.  Once things calm down a bit I'll 
jump back in full strength.

Doug I think you know more ZBLL than I or Dan H by now don't you?  
You have it more spread out than we do, but it definitely seems like 
quite a bit.  Heh heh gotta try and keep up, don't want to get too 
far behind :-P

Chris

P.S.  Bob if you hold a tourny in the spring sometime, PLEASE have a 
4x4x4 BLD event.  I'll even sacrifice some other events if time is a 
problem ;-)

subject: Re: Progress
content:
Today I finished learning all the T1 algs.  I've been more focused on
ZBLL than I have ZBF2L, but I learned all of case 4 for ZBF2L. 
Tomorrow I'll move on to case 5 for ZBF2L and T2 for ZBLL.

I've found some pretty nice algs for some of the T1 cases that aren't
on Chris or Dan's pages.  I want to make a website for my ZB algs just
so I can keep track of which ones I use in case I forget them and have
to look them up or anything, and also just to have another ZBLL page
out there to help other people learning.  Unfortunately I really don't
know a thing about HTML so it would be like learning it as I go along.
 I still want to do this though, so I'll post it here when it's up...
whenever that might be.

-Jason

subject: Messing around with transformation solving
content:
Hey everyone,

I just did an average using transformations sometimes instead of
always COLL when I don't know the ZBLL algs for the COLL case.

Basically, on my slowest COLL cases I do the transformation into T
instead of COLL, since the transformations are all suney type algs and
the T is a ZBLL alg.

17.24, 17.52, 17.46, (14.44), 21.18, (30.01), 16.94, 19.01, 18.94,
22.21, 18.55, 16.20 = 18.52

The 16.94 was actually transforming either an S or AS orientation into
T then doing the T alg.  Some solves were straight ZB, some were fast
COLL.  The 16.20 at the very end was a straight ZB solve, I knew the
ZBLL case, and I think 1 of the 17's also.

I kind of like this, since some of my COLL cases are horrible, and I
think it might be faster to do the transformation then a T alg.

I'm going to mess around with this some more, but even with only
beginning to do this I can get sub-19 with it.  I think this method
will definitely be worth considering for when you know a full
orientation case.

I don't mean to brag here, I'm not trying to rub in knowing the T
orientation.  I just know that you guys will all be to this point very
shortly, so I'm trying to mess around with new techniques and
hopefully you guys will know a really good strategy for handling your
non-ZBLL case solves better than COLL/PLL by the time you get her.  I
definitely agree with Mike that COLL/EPLL is not a good LL strategy in
the long run, so I'm trying to find new things as well.  Mike I do
remember those posts on the regular speedsolving group a while back,
and though I disagreed then I have come to agree now with more practice.

Chris

subject: Re: Messing around with transformation solving

Could you expand on why you believe this.  I started learning COLL 
this week,  with the intention of spending a few weeks learning the 
algorithms,  then a few weeks with a some ZBF2L cases.  I guess 
that's VH.  I was thinking this would be a good starting point to 
begin learning ZBLL in mid-January.  Do you think my time would be 
better spent learning a full ZBLL case and transforming what I don't 
know from the start,  or should knowing COLL be a prerequisite to 
ZBLL,  even without a long-term value?  Thanks.

Matt

subject: Re: Messing around with transformation solving
content:
Hey Matt,

I guess I should have clarified a little more ;-)

COLL/EPLL is extremely fast, and I think when you factor in the 1/12
chance to skip EPLL that it might be faster than most people's OLL/PLL
combos.  I think a really good OLL/PLL set of algs though would
probably win out.

What I don't like is getting a slow COLL case, and ending with a Z
permutation.  As weird as that sounds, and as much as I like the Z
perm in my solving, it is my slowest and longest EPLL alg.  That
double combination can mean a slow LL time compared to the average
COLL/PLL gives you.

On this page: http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/zbstats.html

I have twice done a 100 cube average that shows the number of moves
used in COLL/PLL finish.

I get that, including the EPLL skips, COLL/PLL averages 21.12 moves on
average.  I think Fridrich averages around 19-20 as well so they are
fairly close.  The problem though, for me, is that keeping the edges
oriented for some CLL cases means a slow alg.

Having said that though I have managed sub-17 averages using COLL/PLL
on ZBLL cases that I don't know.  I am certain I have had a full 12
cube sub-17 average that only had EPLL skips for the ZBLL stuff,
meaning that sub-17 is definitely possible.

I don't think a transformation+ZBLL combo used exclusively would be
faster, but rather a combination of COLL/PLL finish (only on fast COLL
cases) and transformation+ZBLL on slow COLL cases would be best.

I think all of COLL should be required before learning any ZBLL
though, since the recognition of ZBLL for me is so heavily based on
COLL.  I use the block recognition technique for ZBLL, and often the
only thing different between three different ZBLL cases is the COLL
case.  They can have the same block structure, but be different COLL
cases.

So I would definitely say to learn COLL, and use COLL/EPLL until you
finish your first orientation case for ZBLL.  After that point,
replace your slowest COLL cases with transformations into your ZBLL
orientation.  At least that is the experiment I am trying, but I have
a feeling it has potential to e very fast.

So when I say slower, I only mean sometimes.  COLL/EPLL is still fast,
but I don't think it is the best option.  It is, however, still a good
one.

Chris

I think COLL/EPLL *is* okay for the long run. I pay enough attention 
doing COLL that I won't get H perm or Z perm. (By mirroring or 
inverting algs as needed.)

And but this point I'm sure you aren't implying that everybody should 
be learning ZB in the same order you and DanH have it layed out. 
Though in hindsight T and U are excellent ones to start off with due 
to their ease of recognition.

And yes, the S-Orientation is a total beast.
